subject: Re: Reading and Writing Speed
messageBody:
Brilliant. I will do this.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Vincent Reilly <vin.reilly@...> wrote:
>
> Here's something that might help. Take a text you find interesting and
> record yourself reading about loud. Then, transcribe it while listening
> to yourself read. Then go over it a few times, listening to yourself
> read so as to check every word for correctness. When spoken, the QS
> words will stand out and make more sense. This is why children are
> encouraged to read out loud in class. Think about all the hours of
> reading you listened to while looking at the printed words.
> On 4/8/2013 8:07 AM, BPJ wrote:
> >
> > On 2013-04-07 23:00, Timothy wrote:
> > > In my case, it took about six months. I was alone in my endeavor,
> > which likely slowed me down since the only person I was communicating
> > with was my future self. A friend of mine managed to master it in half
> > the time since they used it to chat with me occasionally online.
> > >
> > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, "stratocat6969"
> > <john-bergsma@> wrote:
> > >>
> > >> Has anyone achieved reading and writing speed with Senior
> > QuickScript approaching what they could do with normal cursive
> > handwriting? If so, how long did it take to get there?
> >
> > My reading/writing skills in QS aren't that impressive, and
> > besides I have cerebral palsy so my writing speeds aren't
> > comparable to other people's, but I'm a shorthand writer
> > and have about the same reading speed in shorthand and
> > longhand, which shows that you probably can get good
> > reading speed in *any* script with (varying amounts of)
> > practice and more practice. It certainly took less
> > practice to learn to read QS than shorthand, BTW.
> > (I'm using Melin's Swedish Shorthand and my own
> > adaptation of it to English, as well as my adaptation
> > of QS to Swedish as well as ordinary English QS.)
> >
> > /bpj
> >
> >
>
